article: .Twenty years ago, I drove a taxi for a living. One night I went to _ a passager at 2:30 a.m. When I arrived to _ the passager, I found the building was dark except for a single light in a ground floor window. I walked to the _ and knocked, Just a minute, answered a weak ,elderly voice. After a long pause, the door opened. A small woman _ her eighties stood before me. By her side was a small suitcase.I took the suitcase to the car,and then returned to help the woman. She took my arm and we walked slowly toward the car.She kept thanking me for my kindness. It s _ , I told her, I just try to treat my passengers the way I would want my mother _ . Oh, you re such a good man, she said. When we got into the taxi, she gave me a/an _ ,and then asked, could you drive _ downtown? It s not the shortest way, I answered quickly. Oh, I m in no hurry, she said, I m on my way to a hospice.I don t have any family left. The doctor says I don t have very long. I _ reached over and _ the meterFor the next two hours, we drove through the city. She showed me the buildings, _ the manufactory where she had once worked, the neighborhood where she had lived , and the furniture shop _ had once been a ballroom where she had gone dancing as a girl. Sometimes she d ask me to solw down in front of a _ building and would sit staring into the darkness, say nothing. _ , she suddenly said, I m tired, Let s go now. We drove in silence to the address she had given me. _ do I owe you? she asked. Nothing, I said. You _ make a living, she answered. Oh, there are other _ . I answered.Almost without thinking. I _ and gave her a hug. She _ me. Our hug ended with her remark, You gave an old woman a little moment of _ .
